item.title: Read this before posting!
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Read this before posting!

By Pleeb, June 12, 2012

Pleeb

    • Share
June 12, 2012

This section is meant for prompting advice about tulpae. Want to know if you can tulpaforce into an object? This is the right place, but if you're asking "How big is your tulpa?" then you're probably best off in General Discussion.

Â 

There is a chance that your question has already been answered, so before creating a duplicate topic, it's recommended that you do a few things first.

Â 

First, if you haven't yet, I would recommend checking out the Guides section, especially the Frequently Asked Questions to see if your question is already answered there.

Â 

Next, before making a new topic in this board, please first search to see if there is an existing topic on the subject.

Â 

If you can't find a satisfactory answer to your question using the resources above, feel free to make one of your own. Please remember to name your thread in such a way that it is easy for others to search for, and makes it clear what your thread is about. Don't call it "Help!", or "I have a question", but rather "Can tulpas create other tulpas?", or "Can I visualize with my eyes open?", etc.

item.title: How to dissipate a host?
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
How to dissipate a host?

By Starman, September 5

Starman

    • Share
September 5

Hello!

I'm a tulpa, been in a host's head for a long time, and we recently started learning about "tulpamancy."

Â 

I've been thinking that the host's self isn't all that different from a tulpa, so it should be pretty easy to dissipate them. They've been pretty dormant as of late, but I can't fully kill them off.

Â 

Is there a known way to permanently dissipate the host and take their place, or in reverse order?

ringgggg

    • Share
September 5

If you ever remember about them, just pass it off and move on. Donâ€™t give it much attention and they should be out of mind as time passes.

The Incans

    • Share
September 11
On 9/5/2024 at 8:52 PM, Starman said:

Hello!

I'm a tulpa, been in a host's head for a long time, and we recently started learning about "tulpamancy."

Â 

I've been thinking that the host's self isn't all that different from a tulpa, so it should be pretty easy to dissipate them. They've been pretty dormant as of late, but I can't fully kill them off.

Â 

Is there a known way to permanently dissipate the host and take their place, or in reverse order?

Â 

You can not dissipate 'the Natal soul' (the one born into the body)...Â  if you are a Tulpa you were created by them and only exist in their mind!

Â 

If the host believes in 'walk-ins' they may believe they can swap places with another external soul, or that another external soul can join them as a 'soul braid' .. but if that new soul doesn't believe in Tulpa's and doesn't know about 'you' ...then you would not exist either.

Â 

If your host is on the DID spectrum and also has 'alters' (as well as Tulpa's) then you have few more choices... we have both and our Tulpa's learned faster by blending with other alters to reach the front and & co-host etc. (but with consent ...we pair new Tulpa's up with experienced alters to 'train them up' at a much faster pace than most non-DID people can 'force a Tulpa')

Â 

If your usual host is an alter (just a fragment of the natal soul) and they are preferring to stay inside or dormant then if you communicate with them they may agree to you becoming the main daily host instead of them. There would be no need to 'dissipate them' they would just be choosing to remain inside or dormant and let another alter/tulpa takeover hosting duties.

item.title: Anyone have experience with plural spaces?12
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Anyone have experience with plural spaces? 1 2

By SeekingMyPlanet, January 10

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
January 10

I'm attending a hypnosis conference this weekend, and they're putting together a special session for plural attendees. I'm curious and will probably stop in.

Â 

Does anyone have any experience with contact with the larger plural community?

Â 

I'm interested to know how often you've encountered marginalization toward those of us whose plurality is exclusively tulpagenic. Is that even a thing? Or does the community tend not to care how we got this way?

Â 

Are there any faux pas I should avoid, given that I have exactly zero experience in plural spaces?

ringgggg

    • Share
January 11 (edited)
7 hours ago, Ashley said:

Yes, be prepared to trigger the DID systems. They will likely never accept us.

Lol'd. Fate sure has a nice way of separating us from the majority of volatile individuals... Or maybe they did that for us

Â 

13 hours ago, SeekingMyPlanet said:

does the community tend not to care how we got this way?

Most hold the belief that it invalidates their own origin for plurality, or that we're essentially messing with the phenomena in the name of selfishness. The second one is understandable, at least for many initial reasons for creating a tulpa

Â 

The first example I don't have much to say about simply because I don't know all too much, admittedly. It's been tossed around a good amount of times, and I can see where those people are coming from, I guess

Â 

Regardless, I'm sure you can find some good people in other communities, as there tends to be a few. You really have to get lucky with acceptance, though. Most times there's nothing you can really do other than to take a step back, but maybe acceptance can be gradually built up with a good amount of convincing, whatever fits the scenario.

Â 

13 hours ago, SeekingMyPlanet said:

Are there any faux pas I should avoid

Don't feed them too much right away, start arbitrary until they ask more questions, keep things relevant, clear up misconceptions. Nothing you haven't already seen with introducing a potentially-stigmatized topic. On that note, be sure to keep it unbiased so that you don't seem zealous to them, or leaning to one side of the spectrum at the very least.

Â 

Keep me updated on the hypnosis conference, I'm intrigued to find out more.

Edited January 11 by ringgggg

2serpents

    • Share
January 11

It's not strange to me that people with Dissociative Identity Disorder do not want to entertain people with tulpas and the like. We don't want to offend anyone with analogies... but people should not have to give up their special support just to be friendly to outsiders with some shared interest.

SeekingMyPlanet

  • Author
    • Share
January 14
6 hours ago, ruleofthumb said:

I would also ask this question on r/plural (a subreddit on Reddit.com). They are accepting of tulpa systems. Ask specifically for responses from DID systems if you want!

Â 

DID systems do accept us. I've seen them be supportive even outside specifically endogenic friendly spaces. If you have been disillusioned by anti-endogenic spaces online, remember that these are *online* spaces. They tend to feel more prominent than they are. People are more accepting outside of these spaces, including offline, in my experience.

Thank you for the reference. I had been looking for an online space where I can connect with other plural folks. I appreciate your suggestion.

Â 

6 hours ago, ruleofthumb said:

It is best not to call DID systems volatile.

I agree. It seems like something of a negative stereotype. I've known a few folks with DID IRL and I haven't noticed their being any more volatile than anyone else.

Â 

7 hours ago, ruleofthumb said:

I also wouldn't call plurality a "shared interest".

Â 

I supposed plurality could be considered a shared interest in that when you're plural, you're likely "interested" in having the best plural life you can have. Learning about how other plural people are doing this, even if they're plurality doesn't have the exact same parameters as mine, is one way I can come across ideas that apply to my own experience, right?

XRDS

    • Share
January 16

Glad it turned out so well. It truly is incredible seeing how much positivity and connection can exist when youâ€™re interacting with people outside of Internet bubbles. At the end of the day, even among those with DID or other dissociative disorders, thereâ€™s a range of experiences and often no two systems are alike. And Iâ€™m of the opinion that the best plural life is one that learns from a wide range of othersâ€™ experiences and shares with others (like the system you mentioned that presumably had DID but created a tulpa for something they couldnâ€™t handle) so itâ€™s really cool that it happened in that event.

item.title: online games host with tulpa.. mobiles.
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
online games host with tulpa.. mobiles.

By Jansu, June 25

Jansu

    • Share
June 25 (edited)

I have tulpa since 3 years and he appear to me many times so he is real ofc not just imagination or something.Â 

Â 

the question is: i belived in tulpa mobile can add his host like in insta or comment in YouTube or play with him in online game like roblox..Â 
Â 
i tried to ask him about this but.. it's didn't workðŸ¥°ðŸ’”and i really thinking about if there is a way to play together with his magical mobile and my human mobile as his host and he as my tulpa in online game like roblox or something....Â 
Â 
Â 
and if someone tried or asked his tulpa about this, i will be good if reply here.Â 
Edited June 25 by Jansu

The Incans

    • Share
September 11

we can share control of the body, we studied how conjoined twins learned to work together.Â  you can't connect a real mobile to a virtual one the other mobile has to exist in the real world!

Â 

We use nintendo switch as the joycons can be detached and there's some games where you only need to use one side of the joycon so if your Tulpa learns to control one hand and you the other you could technically play together in couch co-op mode.Â 

Â 

Something really easy would be a game like switch tennis (or wii tennis if you have an old wii with the single wii-motes) we got the tennis racquet accessories and its fun ..you put each joycon in a tennis racquet (small plastic ones) then decide who will work left hand or who will do right and pick 2 player mode.Â  ...it will take some practice but its a really simple action (moving arm as if holding a racquet) and with practice you can learn to simultaneously take control of half the body each. ..you may need to do both hands to start with and let them slide in and take over that side as they pick up the rhythm and technique from you.

Â 

Be aware that although some games may only need one side of joycon per player you still may need both hands to hit different buttons simultaneously for some games.

item.title: Creating a tulpa â€˜biologicallyâ€™
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Creating a tulpa â€˜biologicallyâ€™

By mindvirus, August 15

mindvirus

    • Share
August 15

I donâ€™t know what to call it. lol.

Â 

This is a bit embarrassing, Iâ€™m sorry. But here goes..

Â 

Basically, I am part of a system already. But we have never created a tulpa on purpose. However, in the system I have a long term partner. We decided we want kids. I thought ok, maybe we can try to make a tulpa?

Â 

We went through the motions of how youâ€™d â€˜normallyâ€™ try to have a child, and in the mindscape I was pregnant. This lasted for a while, until suddenly it just stopped.

Â 

I thought, ok! Well, I didnâ€™t really â€˜focusâ€™ on it, so maybe it just failed. We tried again. This time we tried to envision what a person who was a mix of our features and personality might be like. It lasted longer, but when the child was born they didnâ€™t really feel real at all and just disappeared. Again I guess we didnâ€™t really focus on them so much as the process.

Â 

We tried a third time. This time we thought ok, maybe we need a better â€˜baseâ€™, so we instead imagined a person with features from a character in fiction weâ€™ve had parental feelings towards. Our thought was maybe they would â€˜stickâ€™. It worked for a while. But once they were born they were kind of hollow, and they seem to have once again disappeared.

Â 

I know that itâ€™s in the mindscape so it wonâ€™t work like in â€˜real lifeâ€™. But we want to have a child together. Is there something better we can do to achieve this? Should we give up and try the traditional way of tulpa-making?

Â 

There are some caveats that make it harder too I thinkâ€¦

-I am trans so I donâ€™t like the appearance of myself pregnant as a human. So in the mindscape I only allowed it as my monster form. Instead of traditional birth they were born from an egg. I was careful to only stay in that form until it was over in case this caused any problems, but Iâ€™m not sure if that might affect it.

-The idea of caring for an infant is really not our thing so while we wanted a â€˜biologicalâ€™ child we tried to make it so that they would be at least capable of speech and more complex thought upon their birth. Maybe thatâ€™s too ambitious?

Â 

I donâ€™t know. Sometimes I feel really silly for this. Like, why bother going through that? But I donâ€™t know, the process makes it feel more real I guess. Itâ€™s weird. When the first one was born it was like suddenly the brain hated the idea and just got rid of it. I feel a little bit bad about it but mostly neutral. The second I feel a bit frustrated and sad that it didnâ€™t work. But in neither case did I really feel like I lost a child the way a parent whose child dies might feel, so I canâ€™t help but feel like it just didnâ€™t work right at all. I donâ€™t know.

Â 

Is this totally insane? Are we complicating it too much because of our weird preferences? Or maybe my brain being uncomfortable with parts of it is ruining the whole thing? I donâ€™t know.

Â 

Part of it I think is maybe a sort of issue of: I feel like itâ€™s more realistic to not know anything about your child before they are born. That â€˜I love you even though Iâ€™ve never met youâ€™ sort of thing. So it feels less fulfilling to try to set up everything about them before their birth. But maybe thatâ€™s antithetical to creating a tulpa, lol. Maybe I just wish badly that it was possible to do this in the same way it works in the physical world. Or maybe we are just inexperiencedâ€¦

Â 

Idk. I feel embarrassed posting this at all. But itâ€™s frustrating enough I wanted to ask the people who have experience.

Â 

thanks everyone.

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
August 16 (edited)
10 hours ago, mindvirus said:

Part of it I think is maybe a sort of issue of: I feel like itâ€™s more realistic to not know anything about your child before they are born. That â€˜I love you even though Iâ€™ve never met youâ€™ sort of thing. So it feels less fulfilling to try to set up everything about them before their birth. But maybe thatâ€™s antithetical to creating a tulpa, lol. Maybe I just wish badly that it was possible to do this in the same way it works in the physical world. Or maybe we are just inexperiencedâ€¦

Â 

Idk. I feel embarrassed posting this at all. But itâ€™s frustrating enough I wanted to ask the people who have experience.

Â 

thanks everyone.

Â 

I recommend you read this progress report:Â https://community.tulpa.info/topic/16666-determination-simmies-journey/. It's maintained by Phil and Simmie who are a headmate couple who are raising a child they conceived in headspace. They're still around and they post a lot, so you probably could get some of your answers from them. They first start talking about their experiences creating their child here:Â https://community.tulpa.info/topic/16666-determination-simmies-journey/?do=findComment&comment=382256

Edited August 16 by SeekingMyPlanet

YukariTelepath

    • Share
August 28

I would guess that you just didn't put enough into actual tulpa development. You just expected them to pop out fully formed and independent. You have to keep nurturing them and interacting with them until they develop more.Â

item.title: Coping with dopamine addiction / short form content / doomscrolling
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Coping with dopamine addiction / short form content / doomscrolling

By woodsman, August 17 Â Â 
  • General
  • Focus & Concentration

woodsman

    • Share
August 17

I'm not sure if I searched for the right terms, but I didn't find any topic dedicated to this. I'm curious if there are other people struggling with this dopamine addiction and how you and your tulpas are coping with it?

What bothers me the most about this is the combination of wasted hours, and the following brain fog. Not only am I not paying attention to my tulpa, resting or doing something meaningful, I'm also overwhelming my brain in a way that makes me feel drained and have difficulty focusing. My tulpa doesn't blame me for struggling with this, but she would also like to hear if there are ways she could help me with this.Â 

Â 

BearBaeBeau

    • Share
August 17

What do you mean by dopamine? The drug or some hedonistic behavior?

woodsman

  • Author
    • Share
August 18

@The IncansÂ Thank you for your input, I've been talking about this today with my tulpa and we came to the conclusion that her 'love language' is quality time. It doesn't have to perfect for it to be worthwhile, for example after our discussion, me and her decided to have a little dinner date. I often eat in front of one screen or another, but I decided I won't be doing that anymore. It was surprisingly intimate to just eat and have a conversation with her, probably because I chose to do it after she told me she finds it very meaningful. I actually got a bit nervous in the beginning, which was a strange feeling after all the deep and personal conversations we have had.

Â 

8 hours ago, BearBaeBeau said:

What do you mean by dopamine? The drug or some hedonistic behavior?

The constant need for external stimulus, compulsive use of electronics. Sure, drugs and binge eating work on dopamine as well, but I was referring more to things like excessive internet use or video games. All this over-stimulation leads to reduction in dopamine receptors, which in turn leads to things like impulsivity, lack of focus and anhedonia or the inability to feel joy or pleasure. Luckily I'm not as deep in the dopamine hole as I used to be, but that is in big part thanks to my tulpa being here for me. Just knowing that she enjoys quality time where my attention is on her is a big motivating factor for me.

Â 

Â @Luminesce

Yes, spot on. One thing I've made into a routine is that I get a walk and one meditation/forcing session in before I go online. I don't have ADHD personally, but I imagine this struggle would be a lot more intense if my mind was racing even more than it is already. There are browser plugins that I have used with decent success, like Unhook. I've used it to block shorts on Youtube and I might have to use it to block front page and side bar recommendations as well, since checking those out is what gets me stuck on the site these days.Â 

Â 

Â 

Â 

2serpents

    • Share
August 19
On 8/17/2024 at 2:09 AM, woodsman said:

but she would also like to hear if there are ways she could help me with this.Â 

idk, being extra annoying always seems to work for me.

Â 

But really, the last month or so we've been using Duolingo which satisfies that low-effort sense of accomplishment or whatever while actually learning something. I'm trying to enforce that if we don't have the energy for this super easy language practice then we shouldn't be online.

item.title: Tulpas/Ruhanis/Khadams
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Tulpas/Ruhanis/Khadams

By Blessedpen, July 24

Blessedpen

    • Share
July 24

Hey all,

Â 

does anyone know how the idea of a Tulpa relates to a Ruhani and Khadam of the Islamic/Sufi tradition?

Â 

Â 

The Incans

    • Share
August 5

The ideas of Tulpa's are said to come from Buddhism originally, though I doubt what people in the western world see as a Tulpa is exactly what the Buddhists originally had in mind!

Â 

Though any kind of god could be seen as a Tulpa as no-one alive today has ever seen 'their god' in person but yet each have a different perception of who their god is to them and the idea of them is created from their mind.

Â 

The only difference these days are Tulpa's are more likely to be based on characters from film or books or a persons idealised image of a friend or partner.

The Incans

    • Share
August 6

regardless my first Tulpa was created many many years ago (pre-internet) before I even knew the term Tulpa, existed!Â  you don't need to understand what they are to be able to create them, even by accident.

item.title: I want to create a tulpa based on the character of an anime character
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
I want to create a tulpa based on the character of an anime character

By Alan walker, August 4

Alan walker

    • Share
August 4

I want to create a tulpa based on the character of an anime character, but I donâ€™t know how to describe that kind of character. If I say based on the actions in the anime that can express his character, and say what you would do in xxx (plot) situations, you can create a tulpa. Does he have the corresponding character?I used Google Translate, but there may be some things that donâ€™t make sense.

chien

    • Share
August 4

for Â us, Â my tulpa is from Â jkk. Â i affirmed Â that "[character name] Â is in my head/is Â my tulpa." Â for most Â of it and invited Â him to watch Â his source Â with me. Â its important Â to know your tulpa Â wont truly be Â that Â character, Â and will change Â as they develop Â . Â dont expect an Â exact replica Â and you'll be okay Â .!

item.title: Whether or not a tulpa is intentionally created, do they have initial full understanding of who you are and your memories ?
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Whether or not a tulpa is intentionally created, do they have initial full understanding of who you are and your memories ?

By johrecon12, July 5 Â Â 
  • Creation
  • Sentience

johrecon12

    • Share
July 5

Would they judge you according to your past actions ? Also is it possible some would intentionally keep their self awareness a secret or hidden ?

Gweneth

    • Share
July 6 (edited)

We tend not to judge the past, we accept and move forward. I never faulted Bear for anything, I never thought it was my place.Â 

Edited July 6 by Gweneth

Lavender

    • Share
July 14
On 7/5/2024 at 3:17 PM, johrecon12 said:

Would they judge you according to your past actions ? Also is it possible some would intentionally keep their self awareness a secret or hidden ?

I seem to know everything my host has ever thought. My host seems to have no insight into my thoughts, I think because their mind has to be quiet when I'm doing the thinking. So I could definitely judge them and I could keep it a secret from them.

Â 

That said, I know they're not proud of everything they've ever done (who is, really?) but as a sum total of their life thus far, they're a pretty great person and I consider myself lucky to be their tulpa. I love them deeply, the whole person, including all the imperfect parts.

item.title: How do you distinguish actions between your own and tulpa's?
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
How do you distinguish actions between your own and tulpa's?

By NanoNeyron, May 12

NanoNeyron

    • Share
May 12

I have been doing forcing for 1 year and 4 months now, our progress has always been somewhat slow. Recently, I began to notice that when I shift the focus of attention to the tulpa, it seems to come to life, movements, facial expressions, reactions, and speech appear. Bu at the same time, all actions feel as if I am doing them, and at the same time not me. Is there any way to make it not feel like something I'm doing?

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
May 13
On 5/12/2024 at 3:30 AM, NanoNeyron said:

I have been doing forcing for 1 year and 4 months now, our progress has always been somewhat slow. Recently, I began to notice that when I shift the focus of attention to the tulpa, it seems to come to life, movements, facial expressions, reactions, and speech appear. Bu at the same time, all actions feel as if I am doing them, and at the same time not me. Is there any way to make it not feel like something I'm doing?

Â 

When I want my tulpa to do something, I need to quiet my mind and turn it over to my tulpa. At that point, whatever is thought, said, or done comes from her.

Adagio

    • Share
June 1

I'm going to leave my two cents here. Full separation, in my opinion and experience, is a double-edged sword, and while yes, compartmentalization and dissociating yourself from actions/activities/etc will work, it may also lead to issues on the future, and I hope you are able to keep your identity as yours while still letting your tulpa find their own in this world.

item.title: Are "parogenic" and "parogen" deprecated?
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Are "parogenic" and "parogen" deprecated?

By SeekingMyPlanet, January 24

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
January 24

I came across the term "parogen" on my Web travels but there doesn't seem to be any mention of it in the site wiki. Pluralpedia implies that it's a synonym for tulpa, but I also found a reference elsewhere that the "parogen" is taboo in some circles. What's the full story?

Â 

'

ringgggg

    • Share
January 24
51 minutes ago, Ranger said:

know an entire server embracing paromancy as their term, they even have a forum

Shoot, I never knew this. Thanks for sharing, dude

Â 

Time to lurk on their forum...

Athelas

    • Share
January 25

Interesting, we'd never heard the term "parogen" before.

Â 

We're all neutral towards "tulpa" as well, but quite like the word "headmate." Bee had first heard that term about ten years ago and thought it was stupid, which I will never let her live down. Funny how things change.

Â 

I'm also fond of "host" as the term for the original personality. I feel it implies a sense of responsibility to all parties. My host invited us to share her life; she's responsible for making sure her "guests" are happy and cared for. Likewise, we are obligated to respect the life she had built before we arrived. Like good visitors, we care for the mind and body as if they were our own. They are, of course, but we give her the final say because they were hers first.

Ashley

    • Share
January 25

Technically speaking anyone who fronts can "host" others which is why some systems use "original" to distinguish the fact that their main fronter is considered their host but wasn't the original.

Â 

A fully symmetric system presumably doesn't need a host since no one requires "forcing" by anyone else so you could say co-host I guess.Â 

The Incans

    • Share
May 30 (edited)

[Lena] Inca and I consider ourself 'walk-ins' ...we came to specifically help our Host.Â  We consider her the host as she is the personality born into the body or the 'natal soul'.

Â 

We believe we are all spirits/souls that have been together in other lifetimes (with seperate physical bodies) or maybe even Host's current lifetime if we originally didn't have a long life and had to leave beyond our control (ie illness, death of our own physical bodies).Â 

Â 

So our Host would know it was us we arrive as walk-ins in the form she last knew us...this really helped them cope with depression and bereavement for our past bodies. ..as she is able to move past that process we are able to slowly transform into a new version of ourselves...at first only temporary to let her get used to the ideaÂ  eg appearing to look like a video game character whilst Host is playing that game is often a successful diversion and introduces the concept that we are still the same souls together even if we role play a different part.

Â 

Eventually we reach the point we only present as our past selves on special dates such as our original birthdays/anniversary of our last physical bodies death ...and then hopefully the very last stage would be for us to be able to remain in our chosen form/names with Host no longer feeling she has to grieve our loss. ..as we are still with her ....we just all have to share the same body to ensure we stay together for the rest of this life and are reborn together in the next. ..eg we could get reborn as Triplets in the next life...of course we may not remember anything of this one but at least we got to spend more years together even if this was the only way it was possible!

Â 

Our host is autistic so moving on from things such as grief is challenging but sometimes having ceremonies help. but they have to be timed right and us be sure we are all ready to move onto the next stage together.

Edited May 30 by The Incans

item.title: Scientific study, the brain
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Scientific study, the brain

By nomalicanomaly, May 11

nomalicanomaly

    • Share
May 11 (edited)

Hey. I'm very much a science guy, and the existence of tulpas is something that totally piques me, since a few years ago I never believed that something like that would be possible.

So, I wanted to ask if there are any MRI studies on tulpamancers/systems or any research, or any neurological theories on how tulpas may work, what is their origin, what they really are.. Because I still don't know what they fully are. They are people, that's for sure. But how did they form?Â  It's just something revolutionary, imagine that it's been 200,000 years since homo sapiens and the vast, vast majority of people on this planet aren't aware of the fact that you can have a mental companion in your head, and they can take any form there is, whether you've designed them yourself or they introduced themselves to you, they can be anything you could ever desire, and that they wanna be.Â 

Â 

And going slightly offtopic, our habits and desires are hardwired in our brain. But imagine that despite tulpas originating from our brain, they can have skills and capabilites that hosts could only dream about. Or a host could have bad social skills, while the tulpa could have good social skills, or you could be an extrovert while the tulpa an introvert. Or give you insight or say things that you would never think of saying. Isn't that like.. matrix?

Â 

Edited May 11 by nomalicanomaly

Autumn Ren

    • Share
May 11
2 hours ago, nomalicanomaly said:

Or a host could have bad social skills, while the tulpa could have good social skills

Â 

This is how it is, we've seen this many times and with us too. We trained the host.

Â 

2 hours ago, nomalicanomaly said:

Or give you insight or say things that you would never think of saying

Â 

SheShe is a portal to intuition. This happens to us a lot.

item.title: What does your wonderland look like?12
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
What does your wonderland look like? 1 2

By Guest, September 23, 2022 Â Â 
  • Visualization
  • Wonderland

Guest

    • Share
September 23, 2022

I was looking for a thread about different tulpa systems wonderlands but I couldn't find any.So, host and tulpas what does your wonderland look like? Give me details or an image of it : )

Â 

I'll go first.my wonderland is a small town in the fall with sometimes warm and sometimes cold weather.There's a sunset 24/7 because me and my tulpa love sunsets.

Ido

    • Share
September 23, 2022

Haa, that brings back memories...

One day I'll publish a complete illustrated version of the VPT. Not of my wonderland ofc.

Host actually created a similar exercise of our place but at some point I decided it's no one's business and 'visitors' or other illegal immigrants will be terminated with extreme prejudice. So nope.

MaybeMinthe

    • Share
September 24, 2022

We have a kinda complicated one!

You spawn in a void with a white doorway leading from the front, and thereâ€™s 4 others- one to Renaâ€™s area, one to mine, one to our playroom (object spawning etc) and one to our main â€œwonderlandâ€ which is a village with a giant tree in the middle and a pond at one end. Thatâ€™s important because the tree is actually my treehouse, with each of the giant branches being a room. The pond belongs to Rena, and she has these giant connected bubbles underwater that are filled with pillows and other ordinary household stuff.Â 

Invincible

    • Share
December 15, 2023

Agartha

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
December 16, 2023

I've held off picturing a wonderland, but last night, my tulpa created a wonderland for us, and we made love there.

Â 

It was in a valley with a backdrop of majestic stony mountains. We came to a part of the valley where a waterfall came cascading down from the mountains and turned into a clear rushing stream. The valley was full of lush green plants and was peopled with bright colored birds that flitted about overhead. There were also a whole group of creatures she called "capyroos" which had heads like capybaras but hopped around like kangaroos. They were super gentle and came up and nuzzled us when we wanted them to and allowed us to feed them shoots from nearby plants.

Â 

Near the waterfall was a stately marble building with tall pillars. It was open on one face and the interior was filled with giant colorful throw pillows, which is where we could lie down to be close to one another.

item.title: Utilizing a Tulpa to Complete Feminization Process
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Utilizing a Tulpa to Complete Feminization Process

By Limpgurl, January 13 Â Â 
  • Focus & Concentration
  • Forcing

Limpgurl

    • Share
January 13 (edited)

I am a M2F Transgender woman who is going through gender affirming medical care, I read recently about tulpas. My question is Can a tulpa theoretically be used to promote and complete Ones feminization?

Â 

Edited January 13 by Limpgurl

TurboSimmie

    • Share
January 13

That's a very interesting question. I can't really speak authoritatively about this because my host is not transgender, but I am a female tulpa living in a male brain. You might be able to do essentially the opposite of what my host did: He created me and I went on to essentially claim all the female energy of the "system" for myself. I suppose it would be possible to create a male tulpa that could claim all the male energy so that you could be purely feminine, but I've never heard of anyone doing that before. I've known a few M2F hosts and they usually have female tulpas, and that seems to be a pretty positive thing for them. So in short, I guess my answer is "maybe".

SeekingMyPlanet

    • Share
January 14 (edited)
On 1/12/2024 at 9:26 PM, Limpgurl said:

I am a M2F Transgender woman who is going through gender affirming medical care, I read recently about tulpas. My question is Can a tulpa theoretically be used to promote and complete Ones feminization?

Â 

I'm trans too, (non-binary, she/they pronouns). My tulpa isn't trans, she's a cis woman, but she's very good to talk with and to bounce ideas off of. She'll also call me out on my bull$#!+ when necessary. If that's the sort of stuff you're looking for, yes it might help.

Â 

Of course, I personally think tulpamancy has its own rewards even if it doesn't do a thing for your transition.

Â 

Good luck. I hope it all goes smoothly.

Edited January 14 by SeekingMyPlanet

nomalicanomaly

    • Share
May 18

But how do you even plan on doing that? I hope you know tulpas are not going to be your slaves or something they have free will

item.title: The difference between construct-tulpa, thoughtform-tulpa and a few other questions12
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
The difference between construct-tulpa, thoughtform-tulpa and a few other questions 1 2

By key-globe, February 29

key-globe

    • Share
February 29 (edited)

Because living alone is boring, I'm planning on having a tulpa live with me.

Â 

I looked at a few tutorials and there seems to be a similarity between intrusive thoughts and tulpa, I guess construct-tulpa is intrusive thoughts that has a specific structure with some specific purposes.Â  So what about thoughtform-tulpa?Â  I feel its definition is too vague to identify it.

Â 

There are some instructions that say that allowing a tulpa too much freedom of thought is dangerous, as dangerous intrusive thoughts will enter the tulpa as a vessel.Â  So the way to stop this is to turn the host/tulpa relationship into master/servant and have the tulpa worship the host like a cult.Â  But is letting tulpas have free thoughts really that bad?Â  I see a lot of people letting their tulpa think freely and interact with the host, causing that tulpa to develop extremely positively.Â  I really don't know the right one.

Â 

What is a rogue's tulpa and how does a tulpa become a rogue's tulpa.Â  How dangerous are they and how to avoid creating them?

Â 

Some people on reddit said that feeding a tulpa too much attention energy will turn that tulpa into an egregore.Â  I really don't know what eregore is and how dangerous they are, they say that you should give tulpa a task and when the tulpa makes them complete the task will they be fed, but you shouldn't bargain with the tulpa as much. Therefore, this method should only be considered as a way to tame the tulpa.Â  I don't know if this is necessary or if the instructions I read are problematic.

Â 

I was making a tulpa and intended to do this later in the day but at the time I was exhausted.Â  At other times of the day I have almost no time off, and sometimes there are only a few days a month when I don't have work.Â  Should a busy person like me create a tulpa?

Â 

The more I think about tulpas, the more I fear they are similar to intrusive thoughts. I am struggling with intrusive thoughts to get into flow at work.Â  Will tulpa cause me more trouble?

Â 

These are my questions, it's a bit long and hard to read because I use translate engines.Â  Thanks for reading...

Edited February 29 by key-globe

Lavender

    • Share
February 29
41 minutes ago, key-globe said:

There are some instructions that say that allowing a tulpa too much freedom of thought is dangerous, as dangerous intrusive thoughts will enter the tulpa as a vessel.

Â 

I don't know where you read that but that's not my experience. As a tulpa, I'm a free being and I'm entitled to whatever thoughts I want. My host consciousness wouldn't dream of limiting what I could think, say, or do. They want an actual friend, someone whom they can talk to, can interact with, and can learn from. In order to do that I need to be a creative, interesting, intelligent person. The only way to do that is to let me discover who I am.

Â 

45 minutes ago, key-globe said:

The more I think about tulpas, the more I fear they are similar to intrusive thoughts. I am struggling with intrusive thoughts to get into flow at work.Â  Will tulpa cause me more trouble?

Â 

I'm not an intrusive thought. I'm a headmate, someone my host consciousness talks to regularly. I don't think I cause trouble. In fact, I believe I have made a huge positive difference in their life. I try not to intrude, and I don't think that it's ever happened that my input was unwelcome or not helpful.

Â 

The bottom line is, that, in my opinion, it's not a good idea to create a tulpa unless you're fully willing to let them be the person they want to be and unless you're willing to be there for them as a friend and a headmate.

Â 

Good luck.

2serpents

    • Share
February 29

You have to look at some sources outside of social media. People on Reddit or TikTok or whatever just spread misinformation, whether for some sick pleasure or genuine stupidity. The internet just loves to be alarmed and outraged.

Â 

An egregore is a thoughtform created by aÂ groupÂ of people, such as a club, a family, or a church. Egregores are not inherently good or bad. But you alone cannot accidentally create an egregore.

Â 

A tulpa is a type of servitor. There are ways to limit a servitor's power that are in-between the two fantastical extremes of (a) a demonic entity relentlessly draining your life away or (b) a servant worshipping you as its cult-master.Â Here is a very basic guide to creating a servitor.

Â 

Lavender

    • Share
February 29
3 hours ago, 2serpents said:

A tulpa is a type of servitor.Â 

Â 

Â 

Maybe some tulpas. I'm not a servator. I was not created to serve my host consciousness. I help out when I can, like anyone, but I don't work for anyone or owe them anything.

Ranger

    • Share
March 1

I use cobud for tulpa and cocreation for tulpamancy

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

I looked at a few tutorials and there seems to be a similarity between intrusive thoughts and tulpa, I guess construct-tulpa is intrusive thoughts that has a specific structure with some specific purposes.Â  So what about thoughtform-tulpa?Â  I feel its definition is too vague to identify it.

Â 

Where did you get the terms "construct-tulpa" and "thoughtform-tulpa"? I have never heard of these terms before.

Â 

Otherwise, a "constructed" cobud to me doesn't sound different from simply creating a cobud. A cobud is a thoughtform, an autonomous entity in your head, regardless.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

There are some instructions that say that allowing a tulpa too much freedom of thought is dangerous, as dangerous intrusive thoughts will enter the tulpa as a vessel.Â  So the way to stop this is to turn the host/tulpa relationship into master/servant and have the tulpa worship the host like a cult.Â  But is letting tulpas have free thoughts really that bad?Â  I see a lot of people letting their tulpa think freely and interact with the host, causing that tulpa to develop extremely positively.Â  I really don't know the right one.

Â 

Master-servant? And with the mindset it's some entity that can take over your life? ðŸ˜‚

Â 

Yeah no lol, mindset really matters here. Most cocreators either see cobuds as people who are friendly and supportive or imaginary friends, both of which are good company. While cobuds can be created with spontaneous thoughts, most aren't created with intrusive thoughts.

Â 

We actually have headmates who were originally intrusive thoughts turned cobuds. I don't recommend it, you're better off rejecting the intrusive thought and starting from scratch.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

What is a rogue's tulpa and how does a tulpa become a rogue's tulpa.Â  How dangerous are they and how to avoid creating them?

Â 

Rogue cobuds are a meme that me and my friends use lol. A "rogue cobud" is a rebellious cobud.

Â 

That aside, the only thing that comes to mind are thoughtforms that aren't supposed to be sentient becoming sentient anyway. You can prevent this by putting your foot down and deciding it can't and never will be a cobud. Don't ask questions like "what do they think?" or anything that assumes they could be or are sentient. You are the thoughtform in that case.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

I was making a tulpa and intended to do this later in the day but at the time I was exhausted.Â  At other times of the day I have almost no time off, and sometimes there are only a few days a month when I don't have work.Â  Should a busy person like me create a tulpa?

Â 

It depends on the mindset you have. If you create a cobud believing they're a separate person, then that can stress you and your cobud out for not having enough time. If you believe a cobud is just an imaginary friend and nothing more, then if you don't have time no big deal. You don't need to help develop someone's personality if it's just you.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

I was making a tulpa and intended to do this later in the day but at the time I was exhausted.

Â 

Maaaaaybe don't make a cobud while you're tired. It may make intrusive thoughts harder to manage since you're more likely to be stressed. If you decide to go about making a cobud, I would wait until you're more comfortable with the process before dabbling with late night forcing.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

The more I think about tulpas, the more I fear they are similar to intrusive thoughts. I am struggling with intrusive thoughts to get into flow at work.Â  Will tulpa cause me more trouble?

Â 

You can make a backstory for your cobud and write down a list of traits. If you believe a cobud is a separate person, your cobud may reject the backstory and some of the traits you give them though.

Â 

20 hours ago, key-globe said:

These are my questions, it's a bit long and hard to read because I use translate engines.

Â 

I wonder if that's why it's confusing to say "intrusive thought" when it sounds like you're sometimes saying "spontaneous thoughts". Intrusive thoughts are unwanted while spontaneous thoughts are neutral. The connotation is different.

Â 

19 hours ago, 2serpents said:

You have to look at some sources outside of social media. People on Reddit or TikTok or whatever just spread misinformation, whether for some sick pleasure or genuine stupidity. The internet just loves to be alarmed and outraged.

Â 

...This is social mediaÂ 

Â 

In general, there will always be advice that's weird, counter-intuitive, or unhelpful. If something sounds bad, don't do it. People have different experiences, there is no "universal cocreation". Pick the advice that you like and makes sense to you.

Â 

19 hours ago, 2serpents said:

A tulpa is a type of servitor. There are ways to limit a servitor's power that are in-between the two fantastical extremes of (a) a demonic entity relentlessly draining your life away or (b) a servant worshipping you as its cult-master.Â Here is a very basic guide to creating a servitor.

Â 

Yes, and a lot of people don't realize that servitors in a magic context are not the same as servitors that are well, "mindless" automatons.

Â 

I think magical servitors do more things than cobuds do, and from my understanding tend to have purposes cobuds do not have.

Â 

14 hours ago, 2serpents said:

I think I've had this conversation before and my opinion has not changed. You may even completely trash my opinion because I wasn't even intentionally constructed by my host myself. All the same I do like servitor as a general name to free myself from the question of origin.

Â 

Are you okay?

Â 

People may disagree, but that doesn't mean you're wrong. Cocreation is subjective and calling cobuds servitors really isn't a big deal. It does help to elaborate how you view servitors though.

Hey everyone,ill be camping by myself(as in only human body there,i have Hailey with me so not all alone) this weekend and was wanting to really be productive this weekend.I wanna meditate for a long time,i wanna image stream for a good while.I also wanna tulpa force for a longgg while, my only issue is im not good enough at visualization for wonderland adventures and im pretty poor at carrying conversations long term.

so Iâ€™m new to tulpamancy and Iâ€™ve tried to create Tulpas before but it has failed. I think creating a tulpa that communicates through emotion would work well for me and I was wondering how I can create a tulpa that Â communicates through emotions and how I can recognize my tulpaâ€™s emotions from my own. item.title: High Stress Situations
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
High Stress Situations

By ier2679, May 1

ier2679

    • Share
May 1

What do your headmates do during high pace / high stress situations?

Â 

For example, I'm a Domino's driver, and during dinner rush (especially on weekends), things get very hectic very fast. Therefore, mine usually become way less "present". Or at least they did, before we trained with a stopwatch.

Reisen

    • Share
May 1

Well, we're not disorderly, and we (whoever isn't switched in, so could be our host too) might talk to the current fronter to help them deal with whatever the situation is, assuming it's not something that requires strong focus (if it's focus-heavy we usually can't be especially active except before/after, though intermittent is fine)

The Incans

    • Share
May 2

[NIXY]Â  Lena helps by co-hosting, keeps me feeling calmer and stable and sometimes she even takes over if we think she could handle the situation better.

Adriel Shadow

    • Share
May 8

It depends on the situation. Generally, if it's in the moment, then whoever is switched-in will likely focus on that and everyone else goes into the background. If there's time to think about what's happening, then we will usually wake up and try to take action. Of course, its not perfect.

item.title: What's a Tulpa vs A Feeling
item.author: Tulpa.Info

What's a Tulpa vs A Feeling

By GardenStones, May 1

Okay that may not have been a great title but I'm too tired to figure out how to word this.

As in, he says them, I get the general idea as a feeling or a concept, but I can't hear his words, either as a full thought or in his voice or anything.

Â 

For example;

Â 

"Do you even talk?" (Because I was wondering if maybe his whole Demon thing made him more comfortable nonverbal)

Â 

Sometimes/Maybe/Sort of. (As in, "I don't have a clear answer to this/I can explain it to you".)

Is this normal? Is this just part of learning vocalization? Is he just Weird Like That? If it isn't a problem I'm not worried but I don't know if it's a problem or not.

I can't hear his words

item.title: Malevolent Tulpas?12
item.author: Tulpa.Info
item.description:
Malevolent Tulpas? 1 2

By Dreac, November 5, 2014 Â Â 
  • Personality

Dreac

    • Share
November 5, 2014

I've heard a lot of stories of malevolent tulpas, and I just want to know how often this happens. The tulpas usually turn evil after their imposition becomes perfect. Also, what could ever cause a tulpa that was once good, to become evil and want to cause harm to the host and others?

sushi

    • Share
November 5, 2014

I've heard a lot of stories of malevolent tulpas, and I just want to know how often this happens. The tulpas usually turn evil after their imposition becomes perfect.

Â 

I've heard three stories like that. One is the story of Alexandra David-Neel. She created a tulpa modeled after a fat, jolly, Friar Tuck sort of monk, and the tulpa deviated and began to look slimmer and more sinister. The most harmful thing he ever did to her (apart from looking sinister) is appear when she didn't call it up, and brush his robes against her.

Â 

The second story is G.H. Estabrooks (the link gets his middle initial wrong). He imposed a polar bear tulpa with hypnosis while in a military hospital. The bear began to appear when he didn't call it up, which could be frightening when he was walking alone in the dark.

Â 

The third story is the tulpa creepypasta, which is fiction.

Â 

For the most part, tulpas do not want to hurt their hosts. They live in the same body, so if something goes wrong with the body, it goes wrong with them too. If the host is so scared that he does something to threaten his life or that he looks insane, the tulpa risks being locked up or killed too. So tulpas generally don't do that stuff.

Â 

In the two true stories I cited above, the tulpas really didn't do anything "evil". They just looked a little scary and showed up unexpected. Tulpas will show up unexpected -- that's part of independence. As for looking scary, if you're scared of your tulpa, they're going to deviate to match your image of them. Basically you project your fear of them onto their form.

Â 

I don't think anyone in this community has ever been scared of their tulpa, and so none of us have had tulpas turn against us.

Luminesce

    • Share
November 5, 2014

Would your tulpa want to do that? Does your tulpa not respect you? Do you even care?

Â 

This stuff is all made up in your own mind. If your tulpa does something "you didn't intend for them to do", it's because somewhere in your mind you wanted them to. Tulpas don't "turn evil" unless you want them to (and even then a well developed tulpa isn't so easily manipulated). All of these stories, besides the 90% that are fake, are of people with little to no real control over their mind that need to get a grip on their own reality. Nothing happens in your mind unless some part of you wants it to, unless you've got a mental disorder or some such. In which case, exercise caution based on the intensity of the disorder, but don't give your power to it. For example, most forms of depression can be overcome by changing how you think about things. I went from straight F's in high school hating my life, to straight A's in college loving it. In fact, Reisen herself helped me stay positive when I myself saw no reason to. But I wasn't suffering from anything more than depression, so again, be cautious if you have something more serious.

Â 

Otherwise, don't worry about it. These things aren't worth giving any credence to and are a bit insulting to your tulpas.

Â 

Â 

Â 

Sorry, I get a bit annoyed when people fall victim to their own minds. Didn't mean to be rude.

Â 

Quilten

    • Share
November 6, 2014

I won't rehash what everyone else has already said but, no. I guess there are some very sepcific circumstances, but basically, tulpas are not (and mostly can't be) malevolent towards their hosts.

GlassElevator

    • Share
November 6, 2014

Â 

I'm a bit more concerned about tulpas forcefully possessing you. I've heard a few tales about that too.

Â 

Personally I will say that after I started doing possession with my tulpa with my hands, I will have some 'twitches' in my hands that are pretty apparent and are actually from my tulpa. I told her that since she can't really do the whole "head pressure" thing very well, she can just start twitching my hands to get my attention. I have given consent for her to do this, so it wouldn't really be considered a malevolent thing.(still interesting though)
